posts.name: Elliot Scher
posts.cooked:
Greetings! We’re encountering an issue with our autonomous paths that could benefit from some guidance. Here’s our code: [GitHub - Team-190/2k25-Robot-Code at event_RIKIN](https://github.com/Team-190/2k25-Robot-Code/tree/event_RIKIN).

We’re using the AutoRoutine API, but when enabled, it causes a significant loop overrun of up to 400 ms. We’re utilizing the autochooser from the choreo documentation, and we’re unsure how to resolve this issue. Any suggestions would be appreciated.

link_counts.title: Extremely Long Auto Delay at Start

posts.name: David Loh
posts.cooked: This thread was useful for solving loop overruns, especially regarding thread priority changes. Be cautious, though, as altering thread priority can lead to unintended consequences if your code remains slow. One suggestion was to warm up the auto builder beforehand, possibly by calling getAutonomousCommand before auto initialization. Additionally, here's the GitHub repository and the relevant code on the dev branch.

posts.name: Elliot Scher
posts.cooked:
Update: The overruns appear to be caused by the paths not being correctly loaded when the robot code boots. From our log data, the robot overruns while starting a new path. The following screenshots show the loop times across three different matches:

Path 1: A screenshot showing loop times for match e14.

Path 2: A screenshot showing loop times for match e15.

Path 3: A screenshot showing loop times for match e16.

We switched to using the trajectory API in Choreo, but the issue persists.

The logs in the images above are from matches e14, e15, and e16. Additional information and logs are available here: [Google Drive Link](https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1PcGuy8G0s4HV6vZXBqoWcRm6kDa_7eey?usp=sharing).

posts.name: David Loh
posts.cooked: Unfortunately, I don't have much experience with Choreo. You're on the right track by using an autonChooser, but I'm not entirely sure about the next steps. Have you considered adjusting the thread priority?

posts.name: Elliot Scher
posts.cooked: No, this thread suggests it’s not a good idea to change the thread priority when using AdvantageKit. We’ve configured the main thread to run with real-time priority, though not the highest. This approach carries certain risks, as documented in the AdvantageKit documentation, which is why we usually don’t recommend it. This can negatively impact the performance of several background threads, affecting vendors, NetworkTables, AdvantageKit itself, and any threads created in user code. Despite this, we’ve conducted extensive testing to ensure these background threads operate effectively under this configuration, although there are still potential trade-offs.

posts.name: David Loh
posts.cooked: Of all the suggestions in that thread, changing thread priority was the only one that solved our problem. We also use AdvantageKit and haven’t had any issues with the performance of background threads since we changed thread priority, so I recommend at least trying it out. However, if you’re at a competition right now, you may want to wait before trying it to ensure you have enough time to thoroughly test.

posts.name: David Loh
posts.cooked: Just curious, are your loop overruns causing major issues? The videos of your autos that I've seen appear to be pretty smooth.

posts.name: Elliot Scher
posts.cooked: They’re causing issues at the start of auto. We tend to hit the reef and miss our first piece. When it overruns, there’s a delay before the robot starts moving.

posts.name: David Loh
posts.cooked: Just in case you haven’t solved your issue yet, we use CTRE’s swerve generator, and we’ve found that disabling their signalLogger on robotInit gets rid of the large first spike.

posts.name: Elliot Scher
Todd
posts.cooked: Extremely importantly, please ensure your project is updated to version 3.1, as the issue mentioned has been resolved in the newer release.

link_counts.title: Disable code reboot while killing robot process by ThadHouse · Pull Request #778 · wpilibsuite/GradleRIO · GitHub

posts.name: Elliot Scher
posts.cooked: Good catch! Unfortunately, that didn't fix our issue. Thanks for pointing that out. I've been meaning to do that myself for a while and just forgot.

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked:
assembling the auto sequence upon enable? I have a problem where when I try to enable the automation tool, it just doesn't work. Every time I click "Enable" on the automation tool, nothing happens. So I need to figure out why this is happening. I think maybe there's an issue with how the auto sequence is being assembled. Maybe the system isn't recognizing that the enable button is supposed to trigger the assembly of the auto sequence. Or perhaps there's some kind of conflict in the configuration settings that's preventing the enable from working properly. Another thing I can check is whether the necessary dependencies or prerequisites are met before enabling the automation tool. posts.name: Elliot Scher
posts.cooked: We’re using Choreo’s AutoChooser class and adding the command sequences in the robotcontainer constructor. The most updated code is available on our GitHub repository at https://github.com/Team-190/2k25-Robot-Code/tree/development.

posts.name: Elliot Scher
Krish Parmar
posts.cooked: After looking at your code, I think your issue is with the auto-chooser. Since it takes a runnable, it doesn't load your command when it's added to the auto chooser but when it's scheduled. This is probably causing your loop to overrun because there's a lot to load, though I'm not entirely sure.

posts.name: David Loh
posts.cooked: I don’t think the issue is with the autochooser. The autochooser loads all paths in the RobotContainer constructor, so it is most likely not causing loop overruns on enable. I know you expressed uncertainty over raising thread priority, but if you have enough time to test before your next competition, I recommend trying it out. We did it for a whole competition, and it eliminated nearly all of our loop overruns. That being said, if your cycle times are still close to 20 ms or you see any signs of thread starvation, like stale CAN frames or odometry that doesn’t update, you should probably switch back.

posts.name: Todd
posts.cooked: It’s strange that so much unaccounted time exists in Tracer. While the ‘UserCodeMS’ timer in advantagekit’s overridden main loop appears reliable, Tracer fails to identify delays despite recurring long loops during autonomous and even into teleop. This raises questions about whether path regeneration is occurring, though your code seems otherwise intact. Adding a print statement can help verify command execution during disabled mode if the AutonomousCommands.java function is selected in the dashboard. Notably, the spikes in delay seem to correlate with overruns caught by Tracer, albeit on vastly different scales—ranging from 20-40 milliseconds compared to the ~150 ms overruns seen in FullCycleMS. The AdvantageKit timing in the ‘Logger’ seems to account for additional processes, but these don’t reach substantial magnitudes. It’s quite confusing. I would suggest disabling the Logger during autonomous to check if Tracer still detects delays.

posts.name: Todd
posts.cooked: I will say something else pre-empting the main loop could certainly cause this behavior. You could always try just setting the priority during the command scheduler like they do in the AdvantageKit templates. Though setting it all the time as a sanity check would be a good test.

posts.name: Krish Parmar
posts.cooked: I do agree that the paths are loaded in the robot container constructor, but there are other parts to the auto that are not loaded then and could cause loop overruns.
